trial_identification.studytitle: Fit Bodies, Fine Minds: Physical activity and cognitive training for cognition in older adults
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The role of physical activity and cognitive training in improving the cognitive performance and functional abilities of older adults

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Studies of normal psychology, cognitive function and behaviour

interventions.interventions:
Exercise, Exercise + Cognitive Training, No-treatment Control. Non-demented, community-dwelling older adults.
Exercise: 16 week program, 3 (60min) sessions per week, aerobic and strength training.
Exercise + Cognitive Training: 16 week program, 2 (60min) exercise sessions per week including aerobic and strength training, 1 (60min) cognitive training session per week covering memory, executive functioning, and mental speed.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Executive Functioning: Matrix Reasoning, D-KEFS Sorting Test, Californian Older Adults Stroop Test.
Mental Speed: Symbol Digit Modalities Test, Simple Reaction Time, Choice Reaction Time.
Fitness: Six-Minute Walk test, Submax, Chair Stand, Arm Curl.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Psychological Well-being: Memory Complaint Questionnaire, SF-36, Health-Related Hardiness Scale, Goldberg Anxiety & Depression Scale.
Feasability measures: adherence (recorded at each training session), compliance (recorded at each training session), satisfaction with program (qualitative - assessed at 16-weeks).

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Current physical activity: less than 60 minutes per weekAvailability: living within 10km of the University of Queensland and available during the dayGender: men and women.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Dementia Screening: score less than 21 on Telephone Interview of Cognitive Status (TICS)Health: Major health problem impeding physical activity and no permission from General Practitioner.

fundingsource.fundingname: NHMRC program grant in physical activity and health
University of Queensland, School of Human Movement Studies (Owen, Bauman and Brown; #301200).

ethicsAndSummary.summary: A feasibility study to compare the relative benefits of a combined physical activity and cognitive training program, a physical activity-only training program, and no-treatment control, for improving cognitive functioning in older adults.
